revisions.rev:
[[Image:Jean Charest.jpg|thumb|Jean Charest is the current premier of Quebec.]] {{main|Premier of Quebec}} This is a list of the '''[[Premier of Quebec|premiers]]''' of the province of '''[[Quebec]]''', [[Canada]], since [[Canadian Confederation|Confederation]] in 1867. Quebec uses a unicameral (originally bicameral) [[Westminster System|Westminster-style]] [[parliamentary government]], in which the premier is the leader of the party that controls the most seats in the [[National Assembly of Quebec|National Assembly]] (previously called the [[Legislative Assembly of Quebec|Legislative Assembly]]). The premier, sometimes called the prime minister, is Quebec's [[head of government]], while the [[Queen of Canada]] is its [[head of state]] and is represented by the [[Lieutenant Governor of Quebec]]. The premier picks a cabinet from the elected members to form the [[Executive Council of Quebec]], and presides over that body. Members are first elected to the legislature during [[List of Quebec general elections|general elections]]. General elections must be conducted every five years from the date of the last election, but the premier may ask for early dissolution of the legislative assembly. An election may also happen if the Governing party loses the confidence of the legislature, by the defeat of a supply bill or tabling of a confidence motion. This article only covers the time since the [[Canadian Confederation]] was created in 1867. For the premiers of the [[Canada East]] from 1840 to 1867, see [[List of Joint Premiers of the Province of Canada]]. The governments of [[Lower Canada]] from 1792 to 1840 were mostly controlled by representatives of the Crown. ==Premiers of Quebec since 1867== {{legend2|#9999FF|[[Parti conservateur du QuÃ©bec]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|#4682B4|[[Union Nationale (Canada)|Union Nationale]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|#F08080|[[Parti libÃ©ral du QuÃ©bec]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|#87CEFA|[[Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan=3|Premier

([[Estrie|Eastern Townships]]) |} ==Living former premiers== {{As of|2011|3}}, five former premiers are alive, the oldest being [[Jacques Parizeau]] (1994â1996, born 1930). The most recent former premier to die was [[Robert Bourassa]] (1970â1976, 1985â1994), on October 2, 1996. {| class="wikitable" !Name!!Term!!Date of birth |- |[[Pierre-Marc Johnson]] |1985 |{{birth date and age|1946|7|5}} |- |[[Daniel Johnson, Jr.]] |1994 |{{birth date and age|1944|12|24}} |- |[[Jacques Parizeau]] |1994â1996 |{{birth date and age|1930|8|9}} |- |[[Lucien Bouchard]] |1996â2001 |{{birth date and age|1938|12|22}} |- |[[Bernard Landry]] |2001â2003 |{{birth date and age|1937|3|9}} |} ==Footnotes== ==References== * {{cite web|url=http://www.assnat.qc.ca/fr/patrimoine/pm1.html|title=Nombre de premiers ministres et de gouvernements depuis 1867|accessdate=2011-03-19|author=Government of QuÃ©bec|work=Informations historiques |publisher=National Assembly of Quebec|date=2010-06-26|language=French}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.quebecpolitique.com/election/index-en.html|title=Ãlections English| work=QuÃ©becPolitique.com| accessdate=2006-12-16|author=Quebec Politique}} ==See also== * [[Timeline of Quebec history]] * [[List of Deputy Premiers of Quebec]] * [[List of third party leaders (Quebec)]] For more lists of this type, see [[Lists of incumbents]]. {{QCPremiers}} {{Politics of Quebec}} {{Canadian First Ministers}} {{Featured list}} [[Category:Lists of Canadian first ministers|Quebec]] [[Category:Premiers of Quebec|*]] [[Category:Lists of people from Quebec|Premiers, List of Quebec]] [[de:Liste der Premierminister von QuÃ©bec]] [[es:Primer Ministro (Quebec)]] [[fr:Liste des Premiers ministres du QuÃ©bec]] [[pl:Lista premierÃ³w Quebecu]] [[uk:Ð¡Ð¿Ð¸ÑÐ¾Ðº Ð¿ÑÐµÐ¼'ÑÑ-Ð¼ÑÐ½ÑÑÑÑÑÐ² ÐÐ²ÐµÐ±ÐµÐºÑ]] {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Premiers Of Quebec}}
